subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}} {{wikipedia|Misogi}} [[File:Misogi_Tsubaki-Jinja.jpg|thumb|250px|{{m|ja|禊|tr=misogi}}: a man performing '''[[misogi]]''' at [[night]] under a [[waterfall]] at {{w|Tsubaki Grand Shrine}}.]]
{{ja-kanjitab|みそぎ|yomi=k}} {{IPAfont|*/mi1so2ɡi1/}} → {{IPAchar|/misoɡi/}} From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=みそぎ|-}}, attested in the ''{{w|Kojiki}}''. Ancient documents have the term written in {{jukujikun|sort=みそき}}, spelled in the ''Kojiki'' with {{ja-l||禊}}, and in the ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'' with {{ja-l||潔}}, {{ja-l||潔身}} and {{ja-l||身秡}}, leaving the original pronunciation of the initial ''miso'' likely unknown. The earliest account of a phonetic spelling is the {{w|Heian period|Heian-period}} ''{{w|lang=ja|日本書紀私記|Nihon Shoki-shiki}}'', with {{m|ja||美曽岐}} ({{IPAfont|*/mi1so2ɡi1/}}). See the {{w|Man'yōgana}} and {{w|Jōdai Tokushu Kanazukai}} articles for more detail on ancient spellings. The {{m|ja|連用形|tr=ren'yōkei||stem or continuative form}} of {{m|ja|禊ぐ|tr=misogu||to [[perform]] [[ablution]]s (on someone)|pos=archaic}}.{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}} Some sources{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}} suggest that this might be derived from {{m|ja|身|tr=mi||body}} + {{m|ja|注ぐ|注ぎ|tr=sosogi|pouring over, into, onto}}, or alternatively from {{m|ja|水|tr=mi||water}} + {{m|ja|注ぐ|注ぎ|tr=sosogi|pouring over, into, onto}}. Considering that {{m|ja|身}} had an ancient reading of {{IPAfont|/mi2/}}, while {{m|ja|水}} had an ancient reading of {{IPAfont|/mi1/}}, the latter is a better potential match.
